instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> = doesn't start, no post, no chime, 105mA
threads.message:
Board is clean and no previous work has been done. DCPS pulls 105mA.

These are missing rails:
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3_CPUDDR</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL>

On <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, EN pins are present as well as V5IN.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> = doesn't start, no post, no chime, 105mA
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at L7430.
Do you get <SIGNAL>1V8_S3</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> = doesn't start, no post, no chime, 105mA
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> = doesn't start, no post, no chime, 105mA
threads.message:
Inspect traces, solders and resistors around <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>.
Be sure R/<CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR> are good.
If all OK, change <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>; maybe need to change <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> = doesn't start, no post, no chime, 105mA
threads.message:
All around <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> was good. Checked traces and solder. Ended up changing <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and it works!
Milion thanks 2informaticos!
